results.headline: A Girl Moves Toward Adulthood

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Kati with an I

results.summary_short: “Kati With an I,” Robert Greene’s endearing documentary, finds virtue in vagueness and significance in the everyday.

results.headline: They Huffed and Puffed and Waited to Exhale

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Your Highness

results.summary_short: A pot-infused fantasy of medieval times, “Your Highness” is a tale of two brothers, one of them a hero.

results.headline: Exotic Pets on the Run
results.display_title: The Elephant in the Living Room

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Elephant in the Living Room

results.summary_short: “The Elephant in the Living Room” Focuses on the misguided and often unregulated American subculture of exotic-pet lovers.

results.headline: ‘Soul Surfer’ Is Bethany Hamilton’s Shark Tale

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Soul Surfer

results.summary_short: “Soul Surfer” tells the story of Bethany Hamilton, the rising 13-year-old amateur competition surfer in Hawaii who in 2003 lost an arm to a shark.

results.headline: Views on Monastic Life

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Mysteries of the Jesus Prayer

results.summary_short: Faces of monastic Christianity are examined at what seems like considerable length in “Mysteries of the Jesus Prayer.”

results.headline: Strip Clubs and Custody Battles

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Meet Monica Velour

results.summary_short: “Meet Monica Velour” may be a teen-geek fantasy but its execution is unexpectedly mature.

results.headline: ‘Meeting Spencer’ Dissects Showbiz Machinations

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Meeting Spencer

results.summary_short: It’s not a backstage comedy, exactly, but “Meeting Spencer” is all about showbiz cogitations and aspirations.

results.headline: The Anguish of Identity

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of To Die Like a Man

results.summary_short: Joao Pedro Rodrigues’s film “To Die Like a Man” is both an unsentimental examination of Lisbon’s drag clubs and a surreal phantasmagoria sprinkled with enigmatic symbols.

results.headline: Man Needs Caffeine Jolt or Reversal of Fortune

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Henry's Crime

results.summary_short: Keanu Reeves portrays a rudderless tollbooth worker who finds himself plotting a life of crime in the muted comedy “Henry’s Crime.”

results.headline: Daddy’s Lethal Girl Ventures Into the Big, Bad World

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hanna

results.summary_short: A girl in the wilds of Finland is raised to be a highly efficient killing machine.

results.headline: Here Comes the Bride, a Wedding Crasher in Pursuit

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Ceremony

results.summary_short: A lopsided love triangle emerges when a privileged pair, portrayed by Uma Thurman and Lee Pace, find their wedding has been crashed by Michael Angarano.

results.headline: A Nature Film in Another Dimension

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Born to be Wild

results.summary_short: “Born to Be Wild 3D” takes an abbreviated look at two women who are doing similar work with wild animals in different parts of the world.

results.headline: A Lush Life Revisited, With Nanny on Board

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Arthur

results.summary_short: A remake of the 1981 comedy “Arthur” stars Russell Brand in the Dudley Moore role of the boozy billionaire.

results.headline: A Bright-Burning life

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of American: The Bill Hicks Story

results.summary_short: Paul Thomas and Matt Harlock’s documentary looks at the life of the comedian Bill Hicks.

results.headline: That ’80s Moment When Nothing and (Almost) Everything Mattered

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Blank City

results.summary_short: The documentary “Blank City” looks at iconoclastic downtown New York filmmakers in the late 1970s and early ’80s.

results.headline: Chess as a Slow Dance of Seduction

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Queen to Play

results.summary_short: In Caroline Bottaro’s slight but captivating “Queen to Play,” Sandrine Bonnaire plays a chambermaid empowered by her mastery of chess.

results.headline: Big Top as Family Business

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Circo

results.summary_short: “Circo,” a documentary by Aaron Schock, travels with a small family-run through rural Mexico.

results.headline: Traveling With Autism

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Wretches & Jabberers

results.summary_short: In “Wretches & Jabberers” the documentarian Gerardine Wurzburg tracks two autistic men’s trips to other countries.

results.headline: When a Parent Dies

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Two Gates Of Sleep

results.summary_short: In “Two Gates of Sleep” two Southern brothers prepare for the loss of their mother.

results.headline: You Don’t Need Superpowers if You Have a Pipe Wrench (and Anger Issues)

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Super

results.summary_short: “Super,” directed by James Gunn, tells the story of an antihero who decides he should be a superhero.
